column4: OK, new question. Can somebody give me a program that will back up a whole partition to a larger HDD, without wiping the contents of said HDD?
gparted allows you to copy partitions, but only by wiping whatever is on the receiving medium
use dd to make an image
man dd. but seriously, just google "dd backup image" or something
that should get you a page that will also explain how to access the resulting image without copying it back to the hd etc
some pages about dd and images: http://www.debianhelp.co.uk/ddcommand.htm and http://www.e-shell.org/index.py?code=tips-5
that dd command you wrote will fail because the output is a directory
and it needs to be able to write to its own partition?
you want "dd if=/dev/sda2 of=/media/External/sda2/fsimage" for example, then your backup will go to a file called "fsimage"
but that wont work cos you are writing back to the same partition by the looks of it
how about "dd if=/dev/sda2 of=/media/external/fsimage"? The resulting file, fsimage, wouldn't interfere with all the other data I have on External?/
yeah, it would go on your root partition
if you output the dd to a file, no other file will be overwritten
nice, that's what I'm looking for. Thanks a lot
the thing about /dev/sda2 is, it is very similar to a file. you could use cp instead of dd for the same effect
the partition to be copied is my dual-boot of WinXP
so I was thinking it would need to be a complete clone of the original data
well, by copying the device, it will be. but the resulting file will be the same size as the disk you backup, unless you compress it
